section.para: Echomix is for people who value their anonymity. Importantly, anonymity is not the same thing as encyrption. Encryption has become standard in modern communication (with the notable exceptions of SMS messaging and e-mail), and most users of text chat and Internet audio are satisfied with protecting the content of their writing and speech. Anonymity, however, means that the identities of people in an electronic conversation cannot be tied to real-world identities by any direct or indirect means. It is reasonable to ask, Why should anyone care about that?

The answer is apparent from the kinds of individuals and institutions who value knowledge of who is talking to whom. Though the law doesn't protect this kind of information very strongly, identifying the members of a network of people in contact with each other is often more useful than knowing the content of any particular conversation.

listitem.para: While the content of telephone conversations is shielded by strong limitations on wire-tapping, criminal investigators generally don't even need a warrant to capture, via pen traps, the identities of people conversing.

The United States Postal Service routinely photographs and stores the address information of mail passing through its system. The USPS almost never denies requests for this information. from law enforcement and others.

Most dramatically, US intelligence agencies use cell phone metadata to track and target suspected terrorists for drone and missile attacks. National Security Agency director Gen. Michael Hayden famously stated, "We kill people based on metadata."

Collection of metadata – All metadata collected will eventually be seized, whether by hackers, police, domestic intelligence, foreign intelligence, or criminals. The only way protect data is not to possess it.
